creator.his_func: In 1575 the Admiralty was organized in the province of Holland. In 1597 the States-General issued the 'Instruction for the Admiralties', organizing the naval defence of the Dutch Republic administratively into five admiralty boards. They were located in the principal ports of the maritime provinces of Holland, Friesland, and Zeeland. Although the defence of the colonies was principally a concern for the chartered companies entrusted with administration, the Dutch naval presence in the Atlantic remained necessary to protect the overseas territorial possessions and Dutch commercial shipping. During most of the 18th century, for example, warships were stationed on a permanent basis in the ports of St Eustatius and Curaçao. Soon after the proclamation of the Batavian Republic in 1795, the five admiralty boards were replaced by the Comité tot de Zaken van de Marine (Committee for the Affairs of the Navy).
